awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Computational Models of Cilia and Flagella in a Brinkman Fluid
awd_abstract_narration:
Motile cilia and flagella are dynamic, elastic, biological structures that exhibit rhythmic motion. Through coordinated beating, cilia in the lung and respiratory tract help to clear the airway of potentially harmful particles and mucus. Impaired cilia motion can result in serious respiratory infection. This impairment can be caused by an altered fluid environment, a characteristic of cystic fibrosis, by defects in the cilia themselves as with primary ciliary dyskinesia, or by other respiratory diseases. Similarly, a sperm is only able to reach and fertilize an egg if its flagellum can propel it forward; impaired motility results in infertility. Cilia and sperm beating is highly dependent on the fluid environment, which contains fibrous, protein networks as well as chemical signals. Understanding this relationship between elastic structure and heterogeneous fluid is vital for development of delivery strategies for inhaled drugs and medicines, new contraceptives, and aiding in infertility due to reduced sperm motility.  This project will focus on the development of new computational models and numerical methods that account for these fibrous, protein networks within the fluid to infer in vivo behavior of cilia and sperm.

Recent experiments have shown that i) sperm-flagella waveforms are altered when immersed in fluids containing networks of large proteins and also with flagellar calcium concentration, ii) the previously-considered `watery' fluid surrounding airway cilia actually contains a network of large proteins, or, 'brush'. This project will focus on identifying emergent waveforms of sperm flagella and airway cilia when nonplanar bending and internal flagellar biochemistry are taken into account. Cilia and flagella will be modeled as slender, elastic, structures immersed in a fluid governed by the Brinkman equation. A regularized framework and fundamental solutions will be used to derive new numerical methods for various confined geometries. The new numerical methods will be computationally-efficient and developed for use on high-performance computing systems. This research will identify factors that modulate sperm progression towards the egg, explore various waveforms of cilia and sperm, and investigate how a 'brush' in the fluid surrounding cilia might affect transport of particles within that fluid.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The interaction between dynamic elastic structures and their surrounding fluid is important in many biological systems, including sperm navigation towards an egg and cilia beating within the airways of the human lungs. Theoretical models of sperm motility and ciliary beating have generally considered prescribed, planar waveforms in a purely viscous and homogeneous fluid. However, oviductal fluid is non-homogeneous, containing a network of proteins (fibers) with an arrangement and density that varies with the menstrual cycle. From laboratory experiments, it is also known that flagellar waveforms (movement patterns of the sperm tail) and swimming speed of sperm change in gels with different amounts of proteins. Thus, the main focus of this research was to develop new computational methods that could be used to study elastic structures such as sperm, bacteria, and cilia moving in a fluid containing a network of proteins. 

Can the presence of proteins enhance swimming? Since it is difficult and costly to perform controlled experiments, we use analysis and computational models to gain intuition for the role of proteins on sperm motility. We employ the Brinkman equation, which represents the homogenized flow through a sparse array of stationary fibers. The model parameter that defines the density of fibers is the resitance parameter; its value increases as protein or fiber density increases. Through analysis, we determined that the swimming speed is a function of the prescribed flagellar waveform, and speeds increased with larger resistance parameter. The idea of enhanced swimming with many additional fibers (higher resistance parameter) seems counter intuitive if one does not consider the total work in the system.  In order to attain the prescribed amplitude and see this enhancement in swimming speed, the amount of work increases dramatically with resistance parameter. Thus, most microorganisms and artificial micro-swimmers would not see enhancement over this range when there is a fixed amount of work in the system. 

Since the analysis was for a prescribed waveform, we wanted to further analyze emergent flagellar waveforms. To do this, we first developed new computational methods to solve for the relevant fluid flow. In simulations, we observe emergent waveforms and the non-monotonic change in swimming speed as the resistance parameter is varied. The enhanced swimming is observed for moderate resistance parameter, in a biologically relevant range of fiber volume fractions. Slower swimming does result for larger resistance parameter since the fibers are preventing the swimmer from moving and achieving the preferred waveform. We also determined that stiffer swimmers representative of mammalian sperm are able to see an enhancement whereas less stiff swimmers such as marine invertebrate sperm do not see this enhancement, leading to the hypothesis that mammalian sperm have adapted to their fluid environment. These results also show that fluid elasticity is not necessary to see an enhancement in swimming speed, which was proposed in previous models.

From Idealized 2D Models to Fully 3D with Accurate Geometries. Many previous models have considered 2D frameworks but since motility is 3D, we have developed new numerical methods to capture the bend and twist of a swimmer in a fluid with proteins. Additionally, since it is computationally expensive to model many swimmers interacting, we developed a numerical method to account for many swimmers with a simplified representation in a triply periodic domain, allowing the simulation of thousands of swimmers. Sperm and other microorganisms are often swimming in confined geometries, thus we have also worked to derive a numerical method to allow for the calculation of the flow near a plane wall.

Intellectual Merit: We have identified how protein volume fractions affect sperm motility, which can be used to aid or hinder sperm motility. This knowledge can also be used in the development of devices such as artificial micro-swimmers, which can be used in drug delivery and bio-sensing. Four new computational methods were developed, which can be used to study microorganisms more generally. This research has led to six manuscripts, four published and two are currently in review.

 

Broader Impacts: This project has resulted in interdisciplinary training for two undergraduate students, one postdoc, and one graduate student. Many scientific presentations were given at conferences to describe the new computational methods and to emphasize the importance of protein volume fraction on swimming. In addition, talks were given a local high school to get students interested in modeling and computational methods.

 


Last Modified: 10/22/2017
Modified by: Sarah Olson
